comments.text:
I've always refused to donate a single penny to cancer research because it 
takes millions and millions to have even the slightest improvement in 
research, so my charitable donations have always gone to helping people who 
are starving or can't afford cures for easily curable diseases because I 
know the relatively little I give can directly make such a massive 
difference to people.﻿

comments.author: Philip Lapierre

comments.text:
This was the best anti-globalization story I've ever read. Congratulations 
on India for maintaining some human decency. If Americans didn't accept 
this form of blackmail for life the company could be charging $5,000 for 
everyone and India probably would not have fucked them. Now that the damn 
has been breached a flood of similar rulings might follow. I see no reason 
if China has manufacturing, the USA has financial, then India can't have 
pharma. And by the way, the '9' in 69,000 overtly indicates pure marketing 
even in the price itself. Disgusting.﻿

comments.text:
Why are people surprised about Bayer coming out with something so 
repugnant.  In WWI they produced Chlorine Gas for chemical warfare.  In 
WWII they produced Zyklon B for the Gas chambers, the Methanol to burn the 
corpses, they paid the SS for a reliable stream of slave labour and funded 
Josef Mengele's barbarous experiments.  The Nuremburg Tribunals indicted 24 
of their executives (13 received extremely light prison sentences) for war 
crimes including slavery, looting and mass murder and by the 50's most of 
them were back at work in the same positions.﻿

comments.text:
How many Americans can afford to be treated @ $69000 can you two? No. 
Actually what Bayer is worried about is not some Indians getting treated by 
the drug, but since the whole world trooping to India to get treated in 
India's to notch medical facilities, India being the world destination for 
what is known as medical tourism, where people come to India as tourists to 
get medical attention in some of the world's best medical facilities in 
India, which means that if a drug is available cheap in India it is also 
available cheap to those travelling to India for affordable medical 
attention.﻿

comments.text:
Bayer has ALWAYS been a scumbag brigade. I remember when that trash sold 
cocaine through the Sears catalog, complete with a syringe. More recently, 
Bayer wheedled into Kansas universities to develop GMO wheat. They created 
a poison in that wheat. It was shipped to China, China rejected it and that 
crap ended up on American tables and has made millions of people sick. It's 
still going on. Those health issues are very serious. Americans are hit 
with serious stomach issues, diabetes, weight gain and the affiliated 
secondary issues -- it's all kinds of medical horrors. I don't know which 
is worse. Bayer or Monsanto -- or the fact that our own government allows 
human garbage like them mess with our medications and foods.﻿

IT is amazing to see so many paid apologists from the Pharmaceutical 
industry here. ALL of the research that creates drugs is done by government 
based labs in universities. These are bought up by the industry at pennies 
to the dollar. How? The oldest trick in the book - bribery of the 
government. Then they claim that they spend a huge amount of money in 
research! Vow! We the people took the gamble using our tax dollars and you 
think you spent that money exclusively? Look up the numbers. R&D money in 
this industry is in the range close to 1-2%. The real expense is in hiding 
the truth about the terrible side effects of their poisonous concotions; it 
is called marketing which accounts for anywhere from 30% to 50% of the 
costs.﻿

comments.author: Kzar Antila

comments.text:
Of primary note, Nexavar is NOT a surefire cure but may prolong a life. The 
side-effects are dreadful as with most cancer treatments. Now, knowing this 
puts it into perspective. We are not talking about a sweeping cure like 
smallpox, polio, malaria, or measles although it is noteworthy that the 
cures for these afflictions were not typically denied to people because 
they were poor. In this case, since it is not a cure are we are talking 
about Nexavar as being a product with an inherent distribution prejudice 
much like a Mercedes-Benz? That human life is factored into this debate 
drags this into a personal introspection on what it means to each of us. As 
human beings we have the ability to decide morals. What clouds the issue is 
that corporations, at least in the US, are regarded by the courts AS legal 
human beings and are able to make such legally valid decisions for the sake 
of profit. What seems to not be factored into the debate is that such 
decisions like these when coming out of any actual human being would be 
considered sociopathic in nature....and the courts have ways of handling 
sociopaths which hasn't been leveraged so far as I can tell. Corporations 
are allowed to keep making these valid and justifiable yet prejudicial 
'business' decisions because that is really what they are...a 
business...and yet they still claim human being status in courts. I would 
suggest that if corporations want to claim their rights as a human being 
they should have the right to also earn it. Is their decision to sell to 
only rich people 'amoral'? Perhaps it should be dragged through a court and 
handled appropriately since such a decision can be defined as sociopathic. 
Is it evil? Most conservatives in this country would support Bayer's point 
of view without seeing the hypocrisy of also laying claim to being the 
political party that God belongs to. Since one cannot serve God and also 
serve mammon, and since Bayer's decision is clearly for serving mammon, 
perhaps it fails that litmus test and is simply evil. An easier scenario 
would be to consider whether Bayer's employees could afford this drug? 
Clearly the representative making the smug claim here is able to. How 
wonderful for him.   ﻿
